metadata.h1: Streamlit can not yet replace Flask
metadata.description: I discuss where Streamlit seems to be heading as well as Flask’s current advantages. Streamlit 1.0 was announced in October 2019. Flask was released on April 1, 2010. Can Streamlit be a better option…

all_paragraphs: I discuss where Streamlit seems to be heading as well as Flask’s current advantages. Streamlit 1.0 was announced in October 2019. Flask was released on April 1, 2010. Can Streamlit be a better option than Flask for Machine Learning production deployments in five years?

Streamlit is a tool to create Web-based frontends with a focus for the Machine Learning scientist or engineer. Specifically, Streamlit uses HTML, CSS, and Javascript but does not need the developer to know HTML, CSS, and Javascript.
The Streamlit team is enabling the Machine Learning scientist to deploy without using Flask, Django, or other tools.
“Streamlit is an open-source app framework for Machine Learning and Data Science teams….All for free.
Streamlit is an open-source but closed framework because:
In this article, I discuss the roadmap of Streamlit, where it seems to be going, and compare it to what Flask has now.

When building websites, you should have a robust framework that can handle all types of features. One of the most popular micro-service frameworks among Python Web frontend software engineers is Flask.
Flask was released on April 1, 2010. It started as a wrapper around Werkzeug and Jinja.
Flask foundation is a plugin architecture. Most plugins are large Python packages. Our developers use over seven Flask extensions. Examples include Bootstrap, SQLAlchemy, Flask8, to name a few.
I find Flask to be a robust framework. It is made more powerful by all the extensions. More importantly, it accommodates your style of programming by offering package extensions that suit you.
“It is up to the developer to choose the tools and libraries they want to use. There are many extensions provided by the community that make adding new functionality easy”.
Streamlit is a closed framework. Currently, the only solution for any custom functionality is to clone the Streamlit Github repo and put in your custom changes.
“The Streamlit plugin system will give you the ability to write arbitrary React or Javascript code and insert it into your app.”
A plug-in architecture for Streamlit is at the community discussion stage.
In a previous post, I wrote:
We have yet to encounter one of our Flask-based ML or DL micro-services that can not be refactored into a Streamlit service.

What can I say? It was the early days. We were excited by the gains in deploying our ML applications with great-looking, interactive Web-GUI frontends. We became the poster-children for upper-management. Then, they showed a Streamlit-based to a client who was outside our firewall AND wanted it.
Ok…? No problem. We asked the Web Application staff (WA-dev) what was a good solution? They told us we had many choices if we used Flask.
We decided to develop a (small) secure login add-on for Streamlit.
The development of the secure login add-on for Streamlit turned out to be a rabbit-hole. Three releases later, we still had not gotten a secure-login past Acceptance Test (AC-Test).
We were pulled out of the rabbit-hole by upper-management who suggested (ordered) that we wait for Streamlit for Teams beta.

Streamlit for Teams beta will be free (for a while?) and available in a “couple months”. It promises authentication, which we hope means secure login. Streamlit also promises logging and auto-scaling (not sure what that is).
At this point, future Streamlit releases will not help us with our st.cache production issue.
Coming up are even more improvements to caching for other function types and some added magic to make everything around caching even more straightforward.
Flask also has caching. Web application dev (WP-dev) uses primary Flask-caching and werkzeug. They told me there are other Flask add-ons for caching.
Background (skip if you don’t want to read a shaggy dog story):

Some of us like to come in early between 6:00 and 6:30 a.m. We noticed, around the beginning of March, the admin booting the computers of the analysts. Analysts arrived between 8:00 and 8:30 a.m. Why this new procedure?
We asked the admin — Why? Because one of the frames in their dashboard required 30 to 45 minutes to appear. The analysts needed their computers booted, so the dashboard was ready when they arrived.

Huh? Why did we have to ask the admin about an issue with the analyst’s dashboard? First, the good news. The analyst really liked the new dashboard. Now, the bad news. It was not broken (in their mindset) and the analysts trusted us to take it away or break the frame. (maybe we are paranoid. They did not actually say that.)
Dev knew it would be “un-acceptable” when the frame took an hour or more three months from now. The frame would be officially “broken” nine to twelve months from now.

The frame had a Deep Learner train and predict part for time-series data. The train dataset was updated early in the morning from test dataset actuals. One of us had carefully written logic to only train on the weekends. However, st.cachecauses training to occur early in the morning Tuesday to Saturday or whenever the train dataset is updated.

Longer-term, to speed up the frame, we are looking at pruning the neural net and/or rewriting portions in Swift. One of us is looking at cPython, while the CTO says, “cloud.” (I say — ” No comment at this time.”). Any ideas you the reader might have, let me know.

AC-Test forbids st.cache for use in production code. We use st.cache for dev experiments, debugging, and unit tests. We think st.cache is designed for the researcher and Kaggler. Please let me know if we are wrong about st.cache.
We want to pass state data between Streamlit micro-services (pages).
Flask does not have this problem as they use encrypted cookies or call args in the URL to pass state.
The Streamlit roadmap calls this "Programmable State":

Right now, getting a Streamlit app to store internal state, like information a user entered in a form, is simply too tricky. .. we want to give you … programmable state so you can build apps with sequential logic, apps with multiple pages, apps that incrementally ask users for input, and so on.
We wait for a future release of Streamlit to pass the state between pages.

Streamlit’s Gallery shows eye-candy-dashboard-like apps (some are quite clever) that Streamlit-users created. Note: All applications are Data Engineering or Machine Learning or Deep Learning. After all, the AI 2.0 Web GUI developers and their users are the target market.
If you want to have your app featured, just tweet it to us @streamlit!
Flask has many galleries. The following are some that include the Flask-Python source code.
Not sure if the reference is the ultimate, but as name says, it is awesome.
A good reference: The Pallets Project
We hope that future releases of Streamlit enable us with the following:
The last item is not in Streamlit’s roadmap but is in our roadmap for Streamlit.
I back off some of my earlier claims about Flask.
Flask has all we need, right now, to production deploy a Web micro-service. Streamlit does not.
However, I still maintain the claims:
We have found that Flask is a mature open framework with a robust ecosystem of extensions.
Streamlit is currently a closed framework of which we depend on future releases. Our greatest hope is that Streamlit becomes an open framework with a plugin architecture solution.
